title: 103_hr899
content: The Act titled "Social Security Domestic Employment Tax Simplification Act of 1993" increases the minimum amount of cash remuneration for domestic services subject to Social Security employment taxes. The Social Security Act is amended to increase the minimum cash remuneration for domestic services subject to Social Security employment taxes. The minimum assessed wages for 1993 are determined based on a formula involving total wages from 1992 and 1950. The Secretary determines and publishes the minimum assessed wages for the succeeding calendar year, based on a formula involving total wages from 1992 and 1950. The Secretary determines and publishes the minimum assessed wages for the succeeding calendar year based on a formula involving total wages from 1992 and 1950. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define wages as cash remuneration paid by an employer. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define wages as cash remuneration paid by an employer for domestic service in a private home, excluding certain services. Additionally, a conforming amendment changes references from "calendar quarter" to "calendar year" in tax deduction regulations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define wages as cash remuneration paid by an employer for domestic service in a private home, excluding certain services. Amendments include changing references from "calendar quarter" to "calendar year" in tax deduction regulations. The amendments made by this section apply to remuneration paid in calendar years after 1992, with the Secretary of Health and Human Services publishing minimum assessed wages for 1993 in the Federal Register. SEC. 3. Amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to coordinate the collection of domestic service employment taxes with income taxes. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 coordinates the collection of domestic service employment taxes with income taxes. Returns for domestic service employment taxes are filed on a calendar year basis, with no deposit requirements. Domestic service employment taxes are subject to estimated tax provisions. For the taxable year of the employer starting in a calendar year, adjustments are made in the application of tax regulations. A transitional rule applies for the taxable year beginning in 1993. Domestic service employment taxes include taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home. The section discusses the payment of domestic service in a private home, excluding certain services, and exceptions where the employer is liable for other employment taxes. The Secretary is authorized to enter agreements to collect state unemployment taxes. The Secretary can enter agreements with States to collect their unemployment taxes on remuneration for domestic service in private homes. The collected taxes will be treated as domestic service employment taxes and transferred to the State's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. The collected amounts will be considered as taxes imposed by chapter 23 for subtitle F purposes. The meaning of 'State' is defined in section 3306(j)(1). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 25. SEC. 3510 coordinates collection of domestic service employment taxes with income taxes. Amendments apply to remuneration paid after 1992. SEC. 4 involves a study on minimum assessed wages for domestic service. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services and the Treasury will conduct a joint study on the effects of amendments made by the Act, analyzing minimum assessed wages' impact on trust funds and evaluating government savings from employment tax changes. A report will be submitted to the House Ways and Means Committee by January 1, 1996. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services and the Treasury will transmit a report to the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee with study results and legislative recommendations.
